item.title: Wynton Marsalis, Founder of Jazz at Lincoln Center, to Step Down
item.description: After 40 years with the organization, the trumpeter and impresario will end his role as managing and artistic director in July 2027.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.media:credit: Jutharat Pinyodoonyachet for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Jazz was dead in this country,” said Gordon J. Davis, the founding chairman of Jazz at Lincoln Center. “Wynton raised it up to make it what it should be: a true art of American culture.”

item.title: They’re Stepping Up on ‘The Pitt’
item.description: Four actors discuss the evolution of their young clinician characters on “The Pitt.” In Season 2 they are a little older, a little wiser and still soaked in fake blood.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski and Sela Shiloni

item.title: Before Tilly Norwood, This C.G.I. Actress Was Considered an ‘It Girl’
item.description: Aki Ross was the computer-generated heroine of the 2001 film “Final Fantasy: The Spirits Within.” The reaction at the time presaged today’s debate over A.I.
item.dc:creator: Carlos Aguilar

item.title: Alive on the Edge of the World, and Suddenly at Its Center
item.description: Inuuteq Storch, a young photographer from Greenland with a show at MoMA PS1, captures daily life in a place much less remote than we thought.
item.dc:creator: Jason Farago

item.title: The Shakers’ Utopian World Sees a Surge of Modern Interest
item.description: A show at ICA Philadelphia joins a surge of Shaker-inspired projects: films, dances, a museum’s expansion. Refracted through new interpreters, Shaker culture bends, and twists.
item.dc:creator: Julie Lasky
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times

item.title: In Hostile Times, Maine Immigrants Cherish Artistic Traditions
item.description: An apprenticeship program that passes on skills like Cambodian dance is persevering despite funding threats and ICE agents.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi and Ryan David Brown

item.title: Dudamel and the Philharmonic Partner With Carnegie Hall on Operas
item.description: Gustavo Dudamel, the New York Philharmonic’s incoming music and artistic director, plans to lead annual operas in concert at Carnegie Hall.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney
item.media:credit: Jutharat Pinyodoonyachet for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gustavo Dudamel, standing at right on the podium, leading a performance at Carnegie Hall in 2024.

item.title: A Puppet Theater Festival in Chicago Brings Warmth and Light
item.description: Crowds are flocking to an annual festival for performances of “A Doll’s House,” a “Macbeth”-inspired witch tale and more featuring puppets big and small.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes and Alexander Coggin
item.media:credit: Alexander Coggin for The New York Times

item.title: Rediscovered Warhols That Warhol Never Saw
item.description: Filmed 60 years ago, the new trove includes footage from Andy Warhol’s Screen Tests series and explicit rolls that reveal the artist as a “porn-oisseur.”
item.dc:creator: Blake Gopnik

item.title: Cairn and Peak Capture the Thrill of Climbing Mountains
item.description: With infinite pathways and incredible tension, video games like Cairn and Peak are recreating the activity’s emotional highs and lows.
item.dc:creator: Lewis Gordon

item.title: ‘The Karate Kid’ and ‘Clueless’ Join National Film Registry
item.description: These films, along with “White Christmas” and “Inception,” are among 25 selected by the Librarian of Congress this year.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez
item.media:credit: Paramount Pictures
item.media:description: Alicia Silverstone in “Clueless,” directed by Amy Heckerling.

item.title: ‘The Moment’ Review: Charli XCX Laughs Last
item.description: The movie glances at artistic concerns like autonomy and authenticity while gleefully testing the divide between a public and a private self.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: ‘The Love That Remains’ Review: Time Goes On
item.description: A family navigates the year after parents separate in this funny, surrealist Icelandic drama.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: ‘A Poet’ Review: The Romance of Misery
item.description: A once-promising writer learns some painful lessons in a tragicomic Colombian tale.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: Jimmy Kimmel Teases ‘Melania’
item.description: The late night host said, “Not since ‘The Terminator’ has there been this much excitement for a movie about a European cyborg.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)

item.title: ‘The Pitt’ Season 2 Episode 4 Recap: Wanna Bet?
item.description: A nearby hospital closes its doors temporarily, sending extra patients and chaos to the Pitt. Time for another office pool.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.media:credit: Warrick Page/HBO Max
item.media:description: Dr. McKay (Fiona Dourif) took a gamble all her own by asking out a patient.

item.title: Trump and First Lady Attend Premiere of ‘Melania’ at Kennedy Center
item.description: Amazon paid Melania Trump’s production company $40 million for the movie and then paid another $35 million to promote it.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and the first lady arrived for the premiere of the film “Melania” at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington on Thursday.

item.title: Clark Art Institute Names Esther Bell as Next Director
item.description: The current deputy director and chief curator, Esther Bell, will become director in July.
item.dc:creator: Ted Loos
item.category: Clark, Sterling and Francine, Art Institute

item.title: Review: Without Its Star, Noche Flamenca Still Shines
item.description: “Irrationalities,” at the Joyce Theater, disappoints only if you are expecting Soledad Barrio, the company’s world-class dancer, who is out with an injury.
item.dc:creator: Brian Seibert

item.title: Will Eisner’s Comics and Graphic Novel IP is Up for Sale
item.description: The intellectual property of Will Eisner, who gives his name to the most prestigious award in American comics, is up for sale.
item.dc:creator: George Gene Gustines
item.category: A Contract with God and Other Tenement Stories (Book)

item.title: Bad Bunny vs. Kendrick Lamar vs. Lady Gaga! Who Should Win at the Grammys.
item.description: The 2026 awards, airing Sunday on CBS, propose a few different ideas about the state of contemporary pop. Here’s who we prefer among the nominees.
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Photos: Gareth Cattermole/Getty Images for ABA; Erika Santelices/Reuters

item.title: Three Great Documentaries to Stream
item.description: In this month’s picks, mountain climbing, dog sledding and government running.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg
item.media:credit: Jimmy Chin/National Geographic
item.media:description: Alex Honnold, the subject of “Free Solo.”

item.title: Newark Museum of Art Names a New Leader
item.description: Lisa Funderburke will be chief executive and director of the state’s largest art museum.
item.dc:creator: Hilarie M. Sheets

item.title: ‘Shelter’ Review: Jason Statham Dispatches Enemies From a Lighthouse
item.description: A teenage girl gets stuck on an island with a rogue MI5 agent. Then, international assassins come after them.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Kenny

item.title: ‘Worldbreaker’ Review: Smashed to Bits
item.description: This postapocalyptic father-daughter story shamelessly recombines overused ideas.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: ‘Send Help’ Review: Rachel McAdams Transforms in Dark Comedy
item.description: A mousy employee and her odious boss battle for dominance in this jubilantly wicked thriller.
item.dc:creator: Jeannette Catsoulis

item.title: ‘Paying for It’ Review: Opening Up the Relationship
item.description: Sonny starts bringing in new lovers, so Chester finds a solution: He starts hiring prostitutes.
item.dc:creator: Chris Azzopardi

item.title: ‘Moses the Black’ Review: An Overcooked Crucible
item.description: Omar Epps struggles to grant this gangland Chicago religious drama divine quality.
item.dc:creator: Robert Daniels

item.title: ‘Islands’ Review: A Thriller Fit for a Volcanic Island
item.description: This slow-burn tale of a tennis pro and a couple gets the low-grade melancholy of a resort town right.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Kennedy

item.title: 27 New Books to Read in February: Toni Morrison, Tayari Jones, Lauren Groff, Michael Pollan and More
item.description: Previously unpublished Toni Morrison; fiction by Tayari Jones, Lauren Groff and Mario Vargas Llosa; Gavin Newsom’s memoir; and more.

item.title: 10 Thrilling Mystery Books Set in a Cabin
item.description: These unforgettable novels set in isolated locations will make you think twice about where to vacation this year.
item.dc:creator: Mary Kubica

item.title: Late Night Praises Ilhan Omar’s Quick Reflexes
item.description: Stephen Colbert said the Minneapolis congresswoman looked “ready to throw some hands” after a man sprayed a substance at her at a town hall.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)

item.title: Sly Dunbar, Whose Drumming Brought Complex Beats to Reggae, Dies at 73
item.description: As one half of the famed rhythm duo Sly and Robbie, he played with some of the biggest names in music, including Bob Dylan and Mick Jagger.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:credit: Markus Cuff/Corbis, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Sly Dunbar in 2014. Rolling Stone ranked him No. 65 in its list of the 100 greatest drummers of all time and, because he was widely sampled, “quite possibly the world’s most recorded musician.”

item.title: Lauryn Hill Will Lead Grammy Tribute to Roberta Flack and D’Angelo
item.description: The artist, who dominated the awards in 1999, will return to the Grammy stage to honor an inspiration and a collaborator.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Stephanie Scarbrough
item.media:description: Lauryn Hill onstage in December. On Sunday, she’ll lead a tribute to two musical titans at the Grammys.

item.title: Bruce Springsteen Releases ‘Streets of Minneapolis,’ a Song Protesting ICE
item.description: The lyrics criticize President Trump and include references to Alex Pretti and Renee Good, who were fatally shot by federal agents this month.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi
item.media:credit: Gareth Cattermole/Getty Images
item.media:description: Bruce Springsteen said he wrote the song on Saturday, the same day that Alex Pretti was killed by immigration agents.

item.title: South Africa Cancels Release of ‘Melania’ Documentary
item.description: The distributor, which was set to release the film on Friday, said it had canceled the theatrical premiere because of “recent developments,” but declined to specify.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:credit: Angela Weiss/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The first lady, Melania Trump, at the New York Stock Exchange on Wednesday, where she rang the opening bell.

item.title: ‘Ulysses,’ ‘Watch Me Walk’ and Other Festival Shows Revisit the Past
item.description: “Watch Me Walk,” “Ulysses” and other offerings from Under the Radar and the Exponential Festival engage with personal histories and the works of literary lions.
item.dc:creator: Helen Shaw
item.media:credit: Richard Termine for The New York Times
item.media:description: Christopher-Rashee Stevenson is among the actors reciting James Joyce’s tale of one event-filled day, verbatim, in the Elevator Repair Service’s retelling of “Ulysses” at the Public Theater in Manhattan.

item.title: Strauss and Haydn Take a Hit as Cash-Crunched Vienna Cuts Budgets
item.description: Amid a broader austerity push, historical sites and an opera stage will shut temporarily, though many worry the closures will be permanent.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova
item.media:credit: Andreas Meichsner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Wien Museum in Vienna. The city is cutting its arts spending as it faces financial woes.

item.title: How Did a 2017 Song Get a 2026 Oscar Nomination?
item.description: “Sweet Dreams of Joy,” from the documentary “Viva Verdi!,” was indeed eligible under academy rules even if it was recorded nearly 10 years ago. Here’s how.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman

item.title: Being the Fun Dad Almost Destroyed My Marriage
item.description: For years, Jordan Carlos left most of the chores and child care to his wife. By the time he realized he didn’t want to be that guy anymore, it was almost too late.
item.dc:creator: Anna Martin, Reva Goldberg, Jen Poyant, Lynn Levy, Daniel Ramirez, Elisheba Ittoop, Dan Powell and Aman Sahota

item.title: Who Will Win the Best Actor Oscar?
item.description: In an exceptionally strong field, Timothée Chalamet, Leonardo DiCaprio, Ethan Hawke, Michael B. Jordan and Wagner Moura each have a way to triumph.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: Theresa Hak Kyung Cha, a Cult Figure Silenced Too Soon
item.description: Theresa Hak Kyung Cha’s poetry, performance and films inspired generations of artists. Never forgotten after her murder, a new exhibition sheds light on her legacy.
item.dc:creator: Aruna D’Souza
item.category: Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive

item.title: When Bruce Springsteen (Hank Azaria) Met Michael Stipe (Michael Shannon)
item.description: Both actors pay homage to rock ’n’ roll greats onstage. But their relationships to their muses — and how they perform their songs — are very different.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik
item.media:credit: Peter Fisher for The New York Times

item.title: ‘The Wrecking Crew’ Review: Super Smash Brothers
item.description: Jason Momoa and Dave Bautista play half brothers on a quest for justice in this lean, mean buddy action flick.
item.dc:creator: Calum Marsh

item.title: On ‘Shrinking,’ Jessica Williams Moves the Needle
item.description: The actor has received Emmy nominations for both seasons of “Shrinking” and knows she’s capable of even more. She just needs the chance to prove it.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.media:credit: Evelyn Freja for The New York Times

item.title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Sondheim
item.description: Judy Collins, Mandy Patinkin, Renée Fleming, Michael R. Jackson, Melissa Errico, Tony Kushner, Sherman Irby and New York Times writers and editors pick 14 songs to seal the deal.
item.category: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (Play)
A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum (Play)
Sunday in the Park with George (Play)
I Wish I Could Forget You (Song)

item.title: Desi Lydic Says Gregory Bovino Got ‘Iced Out’
item.description: “We’re not throwing you under the bus — we’re throwing you onto a bus, and sending it far, far away,” the “Daily Show” host said of the recalled Border Patrol official.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)

item.title: Johnny Legend, a King of Trash Culture, Dies at 77
item.description: His forays into rockabilly music, wrestling and erotic films made him a cult hero in a career as confounding as that of his friend Andy Kaufman.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams

item.title: Meet the Grammys’ Best New Artist Nominees
item.description: Prepare for the awards on Sunday with a primer on one of the four biggest categories, featuring Olivia Dean, Sombr, Addison Rae and more.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Zoladz
item.media:credit: Damien Maloney for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olivia Dean

item.title: Philip Glass Withdraws From Kennedy Center, as Its Symphony Vows to Play On
item.description: Amid cancellations and turmoil, the National Symphony Orchestra is planning to stay. “I cannot make everybody happy,” its conductor said.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gianandrea Noseda, the music director of the National Symphony Orchestra, at the Kennedy Center.

item.title: ‘The Outsiders’ Musical Recoups on Broadway
item.description: “The Outsiders” is the first new musical to open since 2022 to become profitable.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:credit: James Estrin/The New York Times
item.media:description: The musical, which received four Tony Awards, opened in April 2024 at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater.

item.title: BAFTA Nominations: ‘One Battle After Another’ and ‘Sinners’ Face Off
item.description: “Hamnet,” “Marty Supreme” and “Sentimental Value” are also in the running for best film at Britain’s equivalent of the Oscars.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.category: British Academy of Film and Television
If I Had Legs I'd Kick You (Movie)
item.media:credit: Warner Bros. Pictures, via Associated Press
item.media:description: “One Battle After Another” received the most nominations for this year’s BAFTAs, Britain’s top film awards.

item.title: Did Don DeLillo Invent Hockey Erotica?
item.description: Nearly half a century before “Heated Rivalry” skated its way to screens, a budding literary talent pseudonymously published some sporty smut of his own.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter

item.title: ‘Wonder Man’ Review: A Break From the Multiverse
item.description: In Marvel’s latest series on Disney+, Yahya Abdul-Mateen II and Ben Kingsley star as struggling actors who would rather play heroes than be heroes.
item.dc:creator: Mike Hale

item.title: Greenland’s Biggest Band Is Thrust Into an Uneasy Spotlight
item.description: With President Trump threatening to seize the territory, curious listeners have discovered its poppy rock group Nanook.
item.dc:creator: Christian Kriticos

item.title: 62 Discs Offer a Last Word on the Pianist Maurizio Pollini
item.description: Maurizio Pollini’s complete recordings for Deutsche Grammophon have been gathered in one place, allowing listeners to trace his entire career.
item.dc:creator: David Weininger
item.media:credit: Hiroyuki Ito for The New York Times
item.media:description: The eminent pianist Maurizio Pollini, who died in 2024, performing at Carnegie Hall in 2019.

item.title: ‘Wonder Man’ Pushes Marvel Into Unfamiliar Territory
item.description: The studio’s latest series for Disney+ stars Yahya Abdul-Mateen II as a struggling actor whose superpowers are a problem.
item.dc:creator: Adam B. Vary

item.title: ‘Volcano,’ the L.A. Disaster Movie That Boils Over With Unintended Comedy
item.description: Tommy Lee Jones and Anne Heche teamed up in their heyday to save Los Angeles from lava in this big-budget 1997 film that defies all logic to fantastic, farcical effect.
item.dc:creator: Maya Salam

item.title: Seth Meyers Won’t Let ICE Co-Opt the Weather
item.description: “Just think about it, ICE is so unpopular, they want FEMA to not use the word ‘ice,’” the late night host said of the immigration enforcement agency.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)

item.title: Art Stars Honor a Dealer and Her Labor of Love
item.description: William Kentridge, Steve McQueen, Julie Mehretu, Tacita Dean and other leading figures celebrate Marian Goodman, who changed their lives.
item.dc:creator: Will Heinrich
item.media:credit: James Estrin/The New York Times
item.media:description: Marian Goodman in her gallery on West 57th Street in 2016 with a painting by Julie Mehretu. “Everyone felt deeply respected by her, all of the artists that worked with her,” Mehretu said. “That was a very unique dynamic.”

item.title: Kanye West Apologizes for Antisemitic Behavior in Full-Page Wall Street Journal Ad
item.description: The artist formerly known as Kanye West, who first apologized in 2023 before taking it back, said a four-month manic episode in 2025 had led him to embrace swastikas and Hitler.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor and Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Matt Winkelmeyer/Getty Images For The Recording A
item.media:description: Ye at the Grammy Awards in Los Angeles in 2025.

item.title: Review: How ‘Data’ Channels the Shock of Right Now
item.description: In Matthew Libby’s play, a brilliant young computer programmer finds himself at the center of one of the most contentious issues of the moment: immigration.
item.dc:creator: Tim Teeman
item.media:credit: Rachel Papo for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, Sophia Lillis, Karan Brar and Justin H. Min in “Data,” at the Lucille Lortel Theater.

item.title: Memory and Speech Are Their Everyday Struggles. Then They Get to Sing.
item.description: At the Singing Circle in Amsterdam, people with cognitive decline join together to lift their spirits and improve their lives.
item.dc:creator: Nina Siegal
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
